Author: SwampHag4589
Text: There’s a book called “Loving Someone with an Eating Disorder” that’s very helpful for partners and friends of those suffering from ED. It helps you understand and gives you scripts to help open up lines of communication and gives you a whole list of unhelpful behaviors that a lot of caretakers fall into.

Author: lostmybiscuit
Text: hey, it's so great that you're actively trying to figure out how to best support your girlfriend.   make sure to take care of your own mental health and not try to shoulder more than you can cope with. being with someone with an ED can be really fucking scary and you might want outside support sometimes too.   being able to have honest and open communication without guilting or taking out your frustration on each other can help. you might want to think about setting boundaries around things that could potentially be harmful to either of your mental health and autonomy. like, that maybe she shouldn't coerce or recruit you into showing approval of her losing weight or recognition that the framing of needing your "permission" to have the symptoms of a mental disorder she's not entirely in control of worsen might be problematic. but, yeah, you can't really be the Food Police or her ~ ana coach ~, basically.   you might also want to talk with her about things that can trigger her ED symptoms to worsen and what you can do to help when that happens. like, some people find it helpful for their partner to not comment on their body or weight at all, even complements.   educating yourself on EDs can help you feel less helpless and even help you better provide support. there are a lot of different frameworks of understanding EDs out there, some of which aren't [mutually exclusive](https://www.verywellmind.com/what-causes-eating-disorders-4121047), ranging from social and cultural theories to different [neurobiological](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2601682/) [viewpoints](https://scholar.google.com/scholar?output=instlink&q=info:1YYLJyukkf8J:scholar.google.com/&hl=en&as_sdt=0,39&scillfp=14329976667850554634&oi=lle), including [evolutionary biology](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnins.2019.00596/full?utm_source=fweb&utm_medium=nblog&utm_campaign=ba-sci-fnins-anorexia-app) theories, on to even [political economic perspectives](https://www.scienceofeds.org/2015/08/05/eating-disorders-are-a-political-issue-bulimia-nervosa-and-advanced-capitalism/). so reading a variety of sources might be helpful.  even moreso, listening to your girlfriend about her own eating disorder, triggers, and understanding of its cause. providing nonjudgemental and empathetic support and allowing people to feel heard and less alone can be *really* good, even if to you it feels like you're not doing much by doing so.   if you want, you can also educate yourself a bit on the medical complications and the potential medical emergency situations that can arise from [purging](https://www.scienceofeds.org/2013/02/07/medical-complications-of-purging-in-bulimia-nervosa/) and [EDs](https://www.amjmed.com/article/S0002-9343(15\)00582-3/fulltext#/article/S0002-9343(15\)00582-3/fulltext) generally.  this is already getting super long lol but also harm reduction info and the evidence for different types of treatment might be helpful to learn about. I didn't go into specifics about treatment options because I'm not from the UK, but hopefully someone else can answer that part.
